question: CQ CQ WR2 GFO... WR2 GFO, come back. CQ WR2 GFO, do you copy? I'm not getting anything.
answer: Small moves, Captain, small moves.

question: I can't move any smaller.
answer: Try again between the static and 'Hey Jude'; that's where they're hiding.

question: What do I do?
answer: Talk to him.

question: But what do I say?
answer: Just be yourself, Captain. Find out where he is.

question: Where are you calling from, W2P KLD, come back. Pensacola -- ! Where's Pensacola?
answer: Give you a hint

question: Could we hear to China?
answer: On that old shortwave? Maybe on a clear night. Come on now, under the covers.

question: Could we hear to the moon?
answer: Big enough radio, I don't see why not.

question: Could we hear God?
answer: Mmm, that's a good one. Maybe his echo... Okay, no more stalling.

question: Okay, okay... there. Pensacola.
answer: That's a beauty, Captain. Now get some sleep.

question: Do you think there're people on other planets?
answer: Well let's see... the Universe is a pretty big place... And the one thing I know about nature is it hates to waste anything. So I guess I'd say if it is just us, an awful lot of space is going to waste. Time to sleep now, Captain. But you can ask more questions in the morning, okay?

question: Okay.
answer: A comet blows by. We chase it, riding its luminous tail of evaporating ice...

question: Those lily pads must look like clouds to that carp, don't you think? He isn't in heaven; he's in the ground. We just put him there, remember? CQ WR2, this is GFO, do you copy? Dad, this is Ellie, come back. This is Eleanor Arroway broadcasting on 9.2 megahertz. Dad, are you there? Come back. Come back. Come back...
answer: -- rockets through the Rosette Nebula, a vast cloud of glowing red hydrogen illuminated by young hot stars a hundred times brighter than the sun. Their solar wind is blowing out an immense cavity in the interstellar gas and dust.

question: I -- uh -- I was looking for Koestler Hall? Um... I'm not sure. Maybe you could deduce it from lensing a post-spectral starburst...?
answer: We ROAR by a rapidly rotating, flashing pulsar. Cosmic dust filters the light into the shifting spectrum of colors...

question: ... Drumlin said you're been down at Arecibo for the last year.
answer: It's beautiful but it does get a little lonely. Sometimes I think the reason we build these things in such godforsaken places isn't to avoid excess radio traffic but because we're all such pathetic antisocial misfits... Speaking of which

question: He's an incredible prick but I never learned so much in my life.
answer: That's what they all say.

question: Ellie. Arroway.
answer: Peter Valerian.

question: Sounds like a Russian general.
answer: Yavol.

question: ... I'm just so sick of feeling defensive about the things I care about! Or being lumped in with the lunatic fringe by people like Drumlin, when if they'd just put aside their preconceptions for two seconds and look at the facts...
answer: They can't. I think it's against human nature to admit to that level of... insignificance; to not see yourself as basically the center of the universe.

question: It's like the pre-Copernicans who swore the sun revolved around the Earth, or the Victorians at the end of the last century who concluded that all major discoveries had now been made. I mean... try to imagine civilization a thousand years ahead of us -- then imagine trying to explain... I dunno, a microwave oven -- to someone even a hundred years ago -- I mean the basic concepts didn't exist...
answer: 'Any sufficiently advanced technology...'

question: '... is indistinguishable from magic.'
answer: I dunno. I know I should be objective, ice-cold hard-assed scientific about it, but just on an intuitive level -- what's the point of a universe so vast if we're the only ones it it? It'd just be such a... waste of space.

question: Sorry. -- but I've already submitted my proposal!
answer: I'm sorry, Miss Arroway, not only is it too Speculative a subject for a doctoral dissertation, at this point in your career it'd be tantamount to suicide.

question: I'm willing to take that risk.
answer: I'm not. You're far too promising a scientist to waste your considerable gifts on this nonsense --

question: Dr. Drumlin, we are talking about what could potentially be the most important discovery in the history of humanity. There are over four hundred billion stars out there --
answer: And only two probabilities

question: You're --
answer: Two

question: What if you're wrong? No -- I'll grant you probabilities but as a scientist without all the evidence -- you can't deny the possibility -- and I believe even the remotest possibility of something this profoundly... profound is worth investigation -- and worth taking a few risks.
answer: I disagree.

question: Then disagree but don't stand in my way!
answer: What is it that makes you so lonely, Miss Arroway? What is it that compels you to search the heavens for life when there's so much of it being neglected right here at home? I will approve a general thesis on the detection of radio signals from space but that's all. No E.T.I.s. Enough?

question: lies asleep in bed. Peter sits quietly next to her, gently touches her face. Her eyes slowly open. She smiles. ... I keep telling myself okay, that's just the price, you have to do your time doing shitwork before you're allowed to get to the good stuff... but if I have to catalog one more quasar... God, I've missed you.
answer: Any luck on the grant money?

question: Please. Any chance of that died the day David Drumlin was appointed head of the N.S.F. I have been in contact with a few other SETI people; we've been trying to find backing from private investors. I've even managed to scrounge a couple of hours of telescope time here and there...
answer: And?

question: I've examined over forty stars of roughly solar spectral type but so far nothing. Still, we've barely started... ... We've been going after some of the big multi-nationals but without much luck; got a donation from a New York dowager... We've even been thinking about selling T-shirts.
answer: Ellie... even if you do manage to raise the money, have you thought about what it would really mean to follow through on this? I mean a college fetish is one thing, but we're talking about your career. You won't be publishing. You won't be taken seriously... and you could spend your entire life looking and never find anything at all.

question: If we lived at any previous time in human history we wouldn't even have the option of failing -- we'd have to wonder our whole lives, unable to do anything about it. This time, right now, is unique in our history, in any civilization's history -- the moment of the acquisition of technology. The moment when contact becomes possible. We've already beaten incredible odds by being lucky enough to be alive now.
answer: How close are you to getting this funding put together?

question: It's almost there. The hardest part is getting someone to sell us the telescope time.
answer: What if I said I could get Drumlin to agree to sell you time in New Mexico?

question: The V.L.A.?
answer: Thirty-one linked dishes. You could search more sky there in a day than you could in a year here.

question: Peter -- if you can get him to do that for me he'd obviously do the same for you -- we could -- !
answer: Actually --

question: We could be together again --
answer: -- I'm moving to Washington.

question: Greenbank?
answer: I'm going on staff at the N.S.F. To work for Drumlin.

question: But what about your research -- ?
answer: This is a chance to be of enormous help to other people's research -- to have the power to be a real advocate where David's got blind spots --

question: But the work --
answer: 'The work,' Jesus, Ellie, can't there just once be more to life than the work? Okay, maybe that's the only way to get the recognition, win the prizes --

question: Please, you're just as ambitious as I am, more --
answer: Maybe that's the problem. I want... a family, Ellie. I want kids. A townhouse on L street instead of still living like a college kid. A real life. Maybe that makes me a sellout but I don't care anymore. It's what I want.

question: And you think I don't want those things? You think I don't stay up half the night wondering if I've made the right choice living half a world away from you, wondering if any of this is worth what I'm giving up for it everyday? Let's get married.
answer: Jesus --

question: Right now -- we'll drive down to Ramey and get the base chaplain to marry us.
answer: Ellie --

question: I'm serious about this, Peter --
answer: Ellie -- I'm getting married. Her name's Laura. She came up to Owens Valley to do her post-doc about six months after you left.

question: You sonofabitch.
answer: That is true. But it's also true that if I really thought we wanted the same things, I'd follow you anywhere... but the truth is I don't think you want the company. Be honest, El. There's nowhere you'd rather be than sitting out at some remote corner of the world searching for the answers to the mysteries of the universe. And call me crazy, but I just can't compete with that... I'm sorry.

question: Dr. Cullers?
answer: Kent, Kent for Chrissakes. You must be Eleanor.

question: Ellie. Pulsar?
answer: 1919+21. Found a glitch in the timing; probably a starquake.

question: Nice. Where?
answer: Here, right around Centaurus A.

question: This is how you see the sky?
answer: It's how I hear it. The display's just a little something I programmed for astronomers with the misfortune of sight.

question: It's beautiful.
answer: Never seen the optical sky myself, but I hear it's nice too. Doctors Millington, Curtain, Dr. Arroway. Rick's doing black holes at the center of galaxies; Tom's studying globular clusters in the e-band. And Dr. Arroway here will be spending her precious time listening for little green men. All yours, guys.

question: What's that?
answer: Nothing. Okay. Some of us have been a little... not concerned, exactly, but...

question: Tell me.
answer: Last week, about 3 A.M., Fish -- Dr. Fisher -- was on a late shift, and he found her doing laundry.

question: So?
answer: So... there wasn't any clothes in the machine. She was just sitting there on the floor with her ear pressed up against the Maytag. Listening.

question: Pepsi? Tequila?
answer: No, thanks. Peter sends his regards.

question: Oh? How's he doing?
answer: Very well; since my appointment he's been made interim director.

question: Really? Congratulations, by the way.
answer: I'm surprised you even knew it was an election year.

question: 'President's Science Advisor' -- so what, you just spend all your time jetting around on Air Force One now...?
answer: Now exactly. It's... complicated.

question: No doubt.
answer: Ellie...

question: Did I tell you we've expanded the search spectrum? We're including several other possible magic frequencies -- not just the hydrogen line anymore. I was trying to get inside their heads, y'know? And I started thinking, what other constants are there in the Universe besides hydrogen, and then suddenly it was so obvious -- transcendantals, right? So we've been trying variations of pi...
answer: You know why I'm here.

question: It's not enough having my search time systematically cut down -- you know I'm down to three hours a week now.
answer: Ellie, I should have done this a long time ago, certainly before I left the N.S.F., but I wanted to give you every benefit of the doubt --

question: You can't just pull the plug, David.
answer: It's not like you've given me much choice.

question: Meaning...
answer: Meaning I have to go defend a budget to the President and to Congress and you're out here listening to washing machines.

question: I'm searching for patterns in the noise, that's all. Order in the chaos. I'm practicing listening --
answer: The point is, this isn't just scientific inquiry anymore -- it's turned into some kind of personal obsession.

question: The difference being what -- that I refuse to adopt the standard line, that I don't care about the results of my work? Well, I do care. Of course any discovery has to be verifiable, of course it must be subject to all rigors of scientific method, but I refuse to go around pretending I'm some kind of dispassionate automaton when it's obvious to anyone with a brain I'm just not.
answer: No... You're not. But the price has just gotten too high.

question: Goddamnit, they are out there, David --
answer: Then why haven't you detected any signals? If, as you claim, there have been thousands, millions of advanced civilizations out there for millions of years then why hasn't one signal gotten through? It'll take a month or two for the paperwork to go through; you're welcome to stay until then.

question: David --
answer: It was a worthy experiment -- worthy of you; I was wrong about that part. But it's over now.

question: Dr. Arroway, let me first say --
answer: Before you do could you please ask the gentlemen with the firearms to wait outside? This is a civilian facility. Oh, and if you could ask them not to use their radios -- interference. Thanks so much.

question: I'll come right to the point, Doctor. Your sending this message all over the world may well be a breach of National Security.
answer: This isn't a person to person call, Mr. Kitz. I don't really think the civilization sending the message intended it just for Americans.

question: I'm saying you might have consulted us; the contents of this message could be extremely sensitive...
answer: You want to classify prime numbers?

question: It's a civilian facility.
answer: Colonel Jarrod, I'd like a twenty mile radio-silent perimeter put around this installation immediately.

question: And a hundred mile airspace.
answer: And a hundred mile airspace. ... under control for the moment but the longer we wait the more unstable the situation could become. I think you should consider coming here...

question: ... Arrangements also have to be made for the V.I.P.s coming in, mostly religious leaders...
answer: What? Why?

question: The theological ramifications of all this are obvious; the President feels we need to include religious interests rather than alienate them. She's also named Palmer Joss as their liaison; he's requested a meeting with you.
answer: With me.

question: Apparently he's genuinely interested in science. This could be a chance to win him over.
answer: I'm going to convert Mr. Science-is- the-root-of-all-evil? This is absurd, David. We have work to do here, I don't have time to play babysitter to the God Squad.

question: Ellie -- I want you to listen to me, carefully. The minute the implications of this message became clear, this stopped being simply a scientific matter and became a political one -- an extremely complex, extremely volatile one. There are forces at work here you don't understand; I can help you up to a point, but only up to a point.
answer: Are you threatening me?

question: It's not a threat, Ellie, it's a fact -- if you're not careful, you may find yourself out in the cold very quickly. Play ball. Really. It's good advice.
answer: Excuse me. What?

question: Excuse me. What?
answer: We've repeated. A few minutes ago the message cycled back to page one.

question: And?
answer: No primer.

question: How can that be?
answer: I don't know. Maybe there is a fourth layer in there somewhere, but if there is, I sure as hell can't find it.

question: Someone's broken into the system, someone's compromised the fucking -- !
answer: Dr. Arroway, I presume.

question: S.R. Hadden... You compromised our security codes.
answer: Once upon a time I was a hell of an engineer. Please, sit, Doctor. I have guests so rarely, it's important to me they feel welcome in my home. Did you know this was once Yeltsin's flying dascha? That dent is where he threw a bottle of vodka at the pilot. At least that's what the people who sold me the plane said...

question: You live here.
answer: I find it convenient to keep my interests... mobile. Anyway, I've had my fill of life on the ground. After spending much of this century pursuing the evils and pleasures the world has to offer -- after outliving three wives and two children... I find I've had quite enough of planet Earth.

question: Why am I here, Mr. Hadden?
answer: The infamous, unfashionable bluntness. You're here so we can do business. I want to make a deal.

question: What kind of deal?
answer: The powers that be have been quite busy lately, falling over each other to position themselves for the game of the century, if not the millennium. Perhaps you've noticed. Perhaps I could help deal you back in.

question: I didn't realize I was out.
answer: Oh, maybe not out -- but definitely looking for you coat. I understand you've had some difficulty locating the -- what are you calling it? The 'primer' that will make decryption possible... I've found it.

question: You've... found it. What could I possibly have that you would want, Mr. Hadden?
answer: I've had a long time to make enemies, Dr. Arroway. There are many governments, business interests, even religious leaders who would like to see me disappear. And I will grant them their wish soon enough... But before I do, I wish to make a small contribution -- a final gesture of goodwill toward the people of this little planet who've given -- from whom I've taken so much.

question: If I knew you any better I'd say that doesn't sound like you.
answer: That's my girl... Lights. Forgive the theatrics, it's a weakness. Page after page of data -- over sixty-three thousand in all, if I'm not mistaken... and at the end of each...

question: A page-break signal. A period.
answer: Not if you think like a Vegan.

question: You're saying... there is no separate primer in the message -- because it's on every page so the recipient can decipher it wherever he is --
answer: -- even if he doesn't receive the entire transmission. Heaven is the mustard seed.

question: Holy shit...
answer: You'll like this part. A little flashy...

question: Some kind of circuitry...?
answer: Very good, Doctor. I've also detected structural elements, back references, a general movement from the simple to the complex -- all of which would seem to indicate instructions -- an enormously complicated set of instructions -- for building something.

question: A machine. But a machine that does what?
answer: That would seem to be the question of the hour. I want to build it, Doctor. Of course I'm already lobbying through the usual channels of influence and corruption -- but as I said, my colorful past has made many of those channels... difficult to navigate. I need someone on the inside.

question: And in return?
answer: In return... you get the primer -- and with it the power to stay in the game. Do we have a deal?

question: Mr. Hadden, I'm a scientist; I don't make deals... But. If you wish to give me, in good faith, access to your information, I can assure you that I will exert all reasonable efforts to promote your cause wherever it doesn't conflict with the best interests of science... or my better judgment.
answer: That's my girl. Done.

question: But --
answer: Ellie.

question: Peter.
answer: My wife Laura... You look wonderful.

question: You dress up pretty good yourself. How's... the baby? Really. Well. That's wonderful... Well. If you'll excuse me -- I'm paid to mingle... I don't believe I just said that.
answer: It's good to see you, Ellie.

question: You too. Champagne please.
answer: Make that two. Want to fight some more?

question: Yes.
answer: ... What I'm curious about are the wilderness years. You're out there all alone, no money, mocked by the skeptics. It must have taken tremendous faith.

question: I'd say logic more than faith. The odds were on my side.
answer: And what would you have done if the odds had gone against you?

question: I guess I would've felt sorry for the universe.
answer: Spoken like a true believer.

question: What about you? Doesn't all of this shake your faith at all?
answer: How do you mean?

question: Well it's been a while, but I don't recall the Bible saying too much about alien civilizations.
answer: 'My father's house has many mansions.'

question: Very smooth. It's Palmer, right? Where I came from a palmer was a person who cheated at cards. Really though... the Bible describes a God who watches over one tiny world a few thousand years old. I look out there and see a universe of hundreds of billions of galaxies, each with hundreds of billions of stars... I mean burn me for a heretic, but your God seems awfully small.
answer: Who was it who said -- it was a scientist I think -- that one's sophistication is determined by the ability to tolerate paradox -- to hold contradictory ideas at the same time... ... which I suppose is as good a definition of faith as any. Care to test yours? It's okay. I'm a preacher. Your 'faith' tells you that the distance a pendulum swings from the vertical can never get bigger, only smaller.

question: That's not faith, it's physics. The second law of thermodynamics.
answer: And you believe this law with all your heart and soul.

question: And mind, yes. What are you --
answer: So if I let the pendulum go, when it swings back you wouldn't flinch.

question: No.
answer: Don't lean forward. Not even a hair.

question: I flinched.
answer: Only a tiny bit. Even the most devout believer is allowed a little doubt.

question: That's not doubt. That's four hundred years of science fighting a billion years of instinct. I always wondered what you religious types did with your free time.
answer: Now you know. ... It's an old story. I grew up in South Boston, more or less on the streets. By the time I was thirteen I'd tried my first hit of heroin, by fifteen I'd stopped using but I was dealing full-time. By the time I was nineteen I decided I didn't want to live any more, at least not in a world like that. One day I got on a bus; I got as far as Ohio before my money ran out, and after that I just kept walking. Didn't eat, didn't sleep... just walked. I ended up collapsing in a wheat field. There was a storm... I woke up... And that's about as far as words'll go.

question: Can you try?
answer: I had... an experience. Of belonging. Of unconditional love. And for the first time in my life I wasn't terrified, and I wasn't alone.

question: And there's no chance you had this experience simply because some part of you needed to have it?
answer: Look, I'm a reasonable person, and reasonably intelligent. But this experience went beyond both. For the first time I had to consider the possibility that intellect, as wonderful as it is, is not the only way of comprehending the universe. That it was too small and inadequate a tool to deal with what it was faced with.

question: You may not believe this... but there's a part of me that wants more than anything to believe in your God. To believe that we're all here for a purpose, that all this... means something. But it's because that part of me wants it so badly that I'm so stubborn about making sure it isn't just self-delusion. Of course I want to know God if there is one... but it has to be real. Unless I have proof how can I be sure?
answer: Do you love your parents?

question: I never knew my mother. My father died when I was nine.
answer: Did you love him?

question: Yes. Very much.
answer: Prove it.

question: What is it? What's happened?
answer: We've cracked it. Lunacharsky found it.

question: You mean --
answer: You were right, Ellie. You were right all along.

question: looks up in surprise. The applause grows, becoming deafening. People motion for her to stand. Dazed, she does so. The ovation continues. Ellie leans over to speak into her mike. Um... thanks... Thanks very much. I'm not sure what I did to earn that response; I just happened to pick up the phone when they called. David --
answer: Ellie.

question: Do you have a minute -- ?
answer: Actually I'm running late --

question: It'll just take a moment. David... I know we've had our differences... but I've always thought of you as a fair man, even when we've disagreed -- and It's in that light I'm hoping you'll consider my request...
answer: I don't understand.

question: I'm asking for your help, David. I want to go. They'll need someone relatively young, unattached -- and probably a scientist. As the President's Science Advisor you have enormous weight... I'm asking if you'll support my candidacy.
answer: Ellie... you should know that I'm no longer the President's Science Advisor.

question: What?
answer: As of three o'clock this afternoon. I submitted my resignation.

question: You...
answer: Excuse me, I'm late for a meeting.

question: I'm here with Peter Valerian, recently named David Drumlin's replacement as Science Advisor to the President. Doctor, there were loud complaints from the international community last week when it was announced that three of the ten candidates -- were to be Americans. How do you defend that decision?
answer: I believe the response was somewhat disingenuous; when it was determined that national interests would be represented on a pay for play basis it was understood that the U.S., by shouldering close to one third of the financial burden, would be entitled to commensurate representation.

question: You've addressed the political side of the coin but what about the larger issues? On what basis do you choose a human being to represent humanity?
answer: It's a good question. Who do you send? An athlete? A religious leader? A philosopher? A soldier? If you don't know what the Olympic event will be, you send a decathlon champion --

question: And if the event turns out to be chess?
answer: Yes... well, ultimately it was decided that the representative should be somebody fluent in the language the message was sent in -- science. If you'll excuse me --

question: That's from the point of view of someone on Earth -- from the traveler's point of view it'll only seem like two years...
answer: ... Two years is still a hell of a long time -- and as far as we can tell there aren't any provisions in the machine design for storing food, water, even air...

question: ... I can't believe they wouldn't take something as basic as our biological needs into account... ... we're not looking at this from their point of view. It's the first time this has happened to us but it's highly unlikely that's true for them as well. Chances are they've been doing this for thousands if not millions of years...
answer: They knew our level of development. If, as you say, they've done this many times they'd be well aware of the implications.

question: Does it dice and make julienne fries?
answer: You have a question, Dr. Arroway?

question: I question the thinking behind sending the first ambassador to another civilization in armed -- basically announcing our intentions are hostile.
answer: It's designed purely as a defensive device. Call it a reasonable precaution.

question: Call it xenophobic paranoia. Don't you see the absolute absurdity of this? This isn't about them, it's about us -- our violence, our fear and mistrust --
answer: Dr. Arroway, you are entitled to your opinion. But we feel quite strongly that it would by both irresponsible and naive to send a human being into a completely unknown, completely uncontrollable situation absolutely defenseless.

question: You like to drive fast.
answer: So. Is this kosher fraternizing with the enemy like this?

question: Some of my best friends are scientists.
answer: I was referring to the selectees mingling with the selectors.

question: Some of my best friends are scientists. They're saying the machine is alive.
answer: Not exactly. It has organic qualities, but we don't really understand how they're integrated with the mechanical systems.

question: Maybe you're creating a monster.
answer: I don't think so.

question: Why?
answer: It's too... elegant. The degree of economy is extraordinary; it's really the next logical step... Even on Earth technology has always aspired to a condition of nature. D.N.A. outclasses any computer we can come up with; the human body is the most exquisitely designed machine imaginable.

question: In other words, God is one hell of an engineer.
answer: In other words.

question: Relativity. Explain this to me one more time... even if you traveled near the speed of light, when you came back --
answer: If you came back.

question: If you came back... you'd only be four years older -- but over 50 years would have passed on Earth.
answer: Something like that.

question: And everybody you care about would be dead and buried.
answer: If you came back. If you survived at all. Which it's pretty certain you wouldn't.

question: You're willing to die for this.
answer: It's what my whole life's been... aimed at; the only thing that's given it a sense of purpose. I read your book.

question: Really.
answer: Losing Faith

question: What'd you think?
answer: I'm more interested in the story behind the story... How a young man goes from living on the streets of South Boston to being the best- selling media figure rubbing elbows with the President.

question: I won't deny I was ambitious. When I had my... experience... I wanted to tell my story to as many people as possible. I'm the first to admit that process included making some compromises. You didn't answer my question.
answer: I thought it was well-written. Heart-felt. And a little bit naive... But that's just the enemy's perspective.

question: I don't consider you the enemy, Ellie. I'm not 'out to get' technology. I only ask the question
answer: Did you ever stop to think that maybe that isn't science's fault, but meaning's?

question: I don't follow.
answer: Maybe the reason people are having trouble finding meaning isn't because science has obscured it... maybe it's just revealed it isn't there.

question: Do you really believe your life is meaningless?
answer: I don't know. But as a scientist I have to consider that possibility.

question: And yet you're willing to die for this cause, the one thing that's given your life a sense of purpose. Don't you see the contradiction here -- ?
answer: It's getting late...

question: What are you so afraid of, Ellie? You're shaking. You're the paradox here, Ellie. So incredibly brilliant, and yet... What does it feel like to understand everything in the universe except yourself? Ellie --
answer: It's late. We should go back.

question: I think Reverend Joss raises an excellent point. I believe we should discuss the formation of a panel to review any potentially delicate communications before... am I amusing you, Dr. Arroway?
answer: You kill me, you really do. The first truly global, a-political event in history and you can't wait to spin it.

question: How would you propose we handle it, Doctor?
answer: I guess I'd say I trust us enough to believe our response would be something to the effect of, thanks for the advice, but no thanks. But to dilute or censor the truth, for whatever reason --

question: Nobody is proposing we censor the truth here, Doctor. We're simply talking about putting a mechanism in place --
answer: For managing the truth. But the truth won't be managed, sir. It stops being the truth the moment you try. I don't claim to be a perfect example of the human species... far from it. But I think, paradoxically, that's my strength as a candidate. Because I think we need to share the truth of who we are with them -- our strengths -- -- and our weaknesses. To go to them openly, nakedly, and say these are our dreams, these are our fears. What I'm saying, ladies and gentlemen, is that I believe we should make this journey with honesty and integrity or not at all.

question: I am become death; the destroyer of worlds. I wonder if this is how Oppenheimer felt on the eve of the first A-bomb test.
answer: I'd say this is slightly different.

question: Perhaps. But on the off-chance that it is a 'doomsday device' of some kind, I plan to be very far away from your lovely Texas when it is activated.
answer: I thought you were here because you want to go.

question: I do. More than anything. But I am also a realist. Soon this... what is your charming term -- ? Dog and pony show will finally be over, and I will go home.
answer: You're implying that the whole selection process is a sham?

question: You aren't staying?
answer: This... seemed best.

question: Right. Well.
answer: Good luck, David.

question: Ellie... we both know that if I was any kind of a man, I never would've entered this race. That I would have told the President straight out
answer: What would you have me say, David?

question: Nothing. I guess I just wanted to thank you.
answer: Thank you?

question: How far away are we from --
answer: A sunrise and a sunset every forty- five minutes.

question: It's so... small.
answer: Poor, tired, spinning girl... How we feasted on her. And now that we've had our fill and given her a giant dose of the clap... we're pulling out. That's Paris, where my daughter was born. Moscow, where gangsters rule the night and I gave up smoking. So many battles, so many lives... all that sturm, and drang. As if it never happened. If it weren't for a few power grids, you wouldn't know we existed.

question: What's that?
answer: Japanese squid fleet. They use lights to attract them to the surface... then turn them into sushi.

question: It looks like pixie dust... Kent would've given anything to see this. David, too.
answer: Yes. A shame. Still... it'd be worse if they died for nothing.

question: What are you talking about? It's over.
answer: Oh, not quite yet. At least for their sake... ... I hope it's not. Because they're running out of time.

question: You sound like Joseph. You think the world ends with the millennium?
answer: I think whoever sent the message did it because they're worried about us.

question: The gods sent us the machine because they took pity on us.
answer: Wouldn't you if you saw Hitler on TV? Come; I want to show you something. Hokkaido Island.

question: The systems integration site.
answer: Mmm. Look closer. As each component was tested and shipped off to Texas a duplicate was maintained and assembled in Hokkaido -- for backup purposes, of course. We've been right behind you the entire time. You see my problem

question: -- of Hadden Industries.
answer: Want to take a ride?

question: Why don't you come back with me?
answer: Can't. Doctor's orders. The low oxygen/zero gravity environment is the only thing keeping the cancer from eating me alive. It's all right -- I like it here. Ever try sex in zero-G? One more thing, Doctor. If you do meet these Vegans...? Ask them if we have to die.

question: You didn't think I was going to let you leave without saying good-bye... Ellie... the last time we spoke... I said some things...
answer: I remember. You were indelicate, indiscreet and entirely less than tactful... Sound like anyone you know?

question: So. The final countdown.
answer: The final countdown.

question: Oh. I brought you something. During the crusades -- pilgrims who made the journey to the holy land brought back a palm frond to show they'd actually been there. I thought it sort of made sense that Earth is now your holy land, so...
answer: Thank you.

question: You're trembling.
answer: I do seem to be... Maybe because I'm just a little bit terrified about tomorrow.

question: Maybe that's okay. What...?
answer: I'm sorry.

question: What is it? Ellie, what is it?
answer: I'm sorry -- I can't --

question: What?
answer: I can't do this --

question: What are you so afraid of?
answer: Please, Palmer -- if you care for me at all, don't push this now --

question: What are my other options? In fifty years? Never?
answer: Please --

question: I'm in love with you, Ellie.
answer: Don't you understand? I just have to hold it together -- just until tomorrow --

question: And then what? Then you'll be safe?
answer: -- I don't know --

question: Do you really think your life is meaningless, Eleanor? Is that why you're so quick to risk it -- because if your life means nothing then you have nothing to lose?
answer: I can't hear this now --

question: Ellie, there is no reason you have to be alone.
answer: And yet that's always how I seem to end up, isn't it? If you really do love me, Palmer, you'll leave. Now. Please. Someone tell me this is really happening.

question: And yet that's always how I seem to end up, isn't it? If you really do love me, Palmer, you'll leave. Now. Please. Someone tell me this is really happening.
answer: It's really happening.

question: That you, Valerian?
answer: Like it or not.

question: Like it. Almost there. approaches the alien fractal-embossed surface of the machine. That's one small step for a woman... Arroway to control; reading you five by five.
answer: What? Anything happening in there, El?

question: Control, I'm going to continue broadcasting on the assumption... hope... that you can hear me. The atmosphere within the chamber seems to be undergoing some sort of spontaneous state conversion... My breathing seems normal... What was that -- ? whirls around in terror as the light grows dazzlingly bright. I'm falling... sense of enormous acceleration. It's a wormhole, it's got to be, but how do they keep it stable? The energy required -- It's a star, I'm in orbit around a star, spectral type A, maybe early F. Getting weird multiple images here; relativity effects? Accretion disk... gotta be Vega, only... oh my God... They're talking to the whole universe... Okay, okay, clearly artificial, some sort of relay station but the scale is just... tens of thousands of receivers, hundreds... some sort of biotechnology, like the machine but... don't see anything like a docking port... Another wormhole? Bigger this time -- oh God -- Okay. Okay. A series of wormholes, linked together, artificially created, but why would...? Jesus, it's a subway system. Quadruple system... incredible... don't recognize any background constellations... hundreds, possibly thousands of light years from Earth now. So beautiful. So... The physics must be a thousand, ten thousand years beyond us but... oh God... oh God something's... happening... It's beautiful. It's beautiful. I keep saying that but I can't... my mind can't... words... should've sent a poet. I'm a poet and don't know it... Ground control to Major Tom... Relativitistic side-effect? Or -- induced by the transport medium? The gas... Oh, Palmer, I wish I'd had a baby. The center of the galaxy... Docking ports... those are docking ports for other machines... hi, everybody... Now arriving Grand Central Station... floating down... floating... Twinkle twinkle... little star... how I wonder... ellemenopee... ... have to stay awake... stay awake... Please... please... lies in a fetal position. After a long moment she opens her eyes. The familiar RHYTHMIC sound is LOUDER. Her eyes widen... I... remember this... Recording... check, check. Recording, is this on? I think this is on. Okay. I've traveled thirty thousand light years, give or take a few parsecs, to go to the beach. So... Either they've created this environment... or the illusion of this environment, to make me feel at home... or else somehow I am at home -- or else this is my cage at the intergalactic zoo and the tour bus will be along any minute... Or else, of course, I'm completely insane. This should not be discounted as a possibility -- although the fact that I'm questioning my sanity should be a pretty good indication that I am in fact sane... unless of course... unless...
answer: Morning, Captain.

question: Tears come to her eyes... she approaches, staring... He takes her hand --
answer: I've missed you.

question: Dad...
answer: It's okay...

question: I used... I used to dream you were alive... and then I'd wake up and lose you all over again.
answer: I'm sorry I couldn't be there for you, sweetheart.

question: Dad... But tell me, how did... I mean how can...? You're not real. None of this is.
answer: That's my scientist.

question: So. Are you an hallucination? Or are little gear trains and circuit boards under your skin?
answer: Am I artifact or dream? You might ask that about anything.

question: But you're so... I mean how could you possibly...? When I was unconscious. You... downloaded... my thoughts, my memories, even... This beach. I've never been here but I remember... it's how I always imagined... Pensacola.
answer: We thought this might make things a little easier. ... although this is nice too.

question: So who -- what -- are you?
answer: Originally just another species like yourselves. Well, not like you at all actually, but...

question: Can you show me?
answer: Small moves, Captain, small moves.

question: Why did you contact us?
answer: You contacted us. We were simply listening. We've been listening for millions of years.

question: And those other docking ports I saw... I mean... there are others?
answer: Many others.

question: And they all travel here through this wormhole subway system you built.
answer: Oh, we didn't build it. The transit system has been in place for billions of years; we're just its... caretakers.

question: So who...?
answer: We don't know. Whoever they were, they were gone long before we ever got here.

question: The scale... it's just... So all the civilizations you detect; they all end up coming here?
answer: Not all. Some choose to stay at home and dream their dreams. Some never make it this far.

question: So we passed some kind of test?
answer: You have your mother's hands... There are no tests, Ellie. We don't sit in judgment. Think of us more as... librarians. Curators of the Universe's rarest and most valuable creation... As many civilizations as we've found, compared to the vastness of space... ... life is unspeakably rare. So whenever we do find another civilization, especially one that's... struggling... We send a message. Sometimes we can offer help. Sometimes we can't. But we always try. Life is simply too precious not to.

question: Can you help us?
answer: You're an interesting species; an interesting mix. Capable of such exquisite dreams; such horrifying nightmares. Technologically you've advanced very quickly -- some think too quickly... and yet... You're so lost. So cut off... and so sad.

question: We are alone. For millions of years we've searched the cosmos... and after all the suffering, after all the chaos and desolation of the void -- the one thing we've found that makes the emptiness bearable is each other. That's why I sent the message. That's why I made contact.
answer: Who are you?

question: Am I one... or many?
answer: The librarian... or the library...? ... all those voices... you gather them all together. Millions of intelligences in one consciousness... and now we're a part of it.

question: You always have been. We're all descendants of the same stars, Ellie. All made of the same primordial atoms.
answer: So. What happens now?

question: Now... you go home.
answer: No! I mean... why so soon?

question: If we don't engineer a consistent causality it'll work itself out on its own, and that's almost always worse. Ellie, according to your physics none of this is possible. A lot of it you're simply not capable of understanding, not yet. No offense.
answer: None taken... but ... do we get to come back? Others of my kind, I mean.

question: Eventually you'll get here on your own. This was just the first step; in time you'll take another.
answer: But -- other people from our planet should see what I've seen -- they should witness this for themselves.

question: That isn't the way it works.
answer: But you said you wanted to help -- don't you see what it would mean?

question: No more stalling, Captain.
answer: Please -- if you... downloaded... everything about us you know the problems we face, the impact it could have -- it could make the difference --

question: Ellie... this is the way it's been done for billions of years... ... but we'll consider your request. It's time to go home now.
answer: No. Please.

question: Childhood is over, Ellie. It's time to grow up.
answer: No...

question: No...
answer: Ellie -- are you okay?

question: I'm -- I'm fine.
answer: Thank God. When we lost contact, I thought -- we thought... but you're okay. We're still trying to determine the nature of the malfunction. Did you notice anything at all that --

question: Wait -- hold on a minute --
answer: It's all right, the important thing is you're safe --

question: Peter, what are you talking about? What malfunction? What day is this?
answer: What day?

question: How long was I gone?
answer: Ellie... we saw you enter the machine. The benzels spun up, generating some sort of atmospheric disturbance. The benzels spun down. And then... just now... you stepped out. We were out of radio contact exactly... seven minutes and thirty- five seconds. The machine never went anywhere.

question: I'm fine -- No -- could somebody please just -- Peter... What is going on? Has everyone gone completely insane?
answer: That's one way of putting it. Kitz, the President, the I.S.C. have shut down all official communications; there've also been reports of riots flaring up across the U.S. and Europe. Until we figure out what went wrong things may get rough, especially for you --

question: I'm afraid that's not a satisfactory answer, Doctor. We spent two trillion dollars. You walked into that machine with the hopes and prayers of an entire planet with you, and you stepped out with nothing. Those people are going to want more than idle speculation and conjecture -- they're going to want answers -- and I hope for all our sakes you can come up with them.
answer: Put him through. Well?

question: Nothing. Apparently the surface began to ossify immediately after she emerged; all subsequent attempts to re-enter the machine have failed... ... as have all attempts at internal analysis. We've tried sonargrams, magnetic resonance, gamma rays; it's completely impenetrable.
answer: Recommendations?

question: I don't know. Maybe we built the damn thing wrong. Maybe it was all a hoax... The safest thing would probably be to do a Chernobyl; encase it in concrete.
answer: Have your department make a full report.

question: Oh, Ellie...
answer: Hi.

question: Hi.
answer: I'm assuming you read my deposition.

question: It was quite a page turner.
answer: Pretty ironic, huh? I had to go all the way to the center of the galaxy... Just to find you. So. I'm assuming they sent you here to administer last rites?

question: I'm not sure it's come to that.
answer: They don't believe me.

question: I do.
answer: You're sure you want to? In the universe I saw we're not exactly the stars of the show. What happened to me makes us all seem pretty damn small.

question: It also makes God enormous. I think of the scope of your universe, Ellie... and it takes my breath away. As it will everyone else's.
answer: I don't have any proof, Palmer.

question: Ellie, you're the proof. You tell them your story. Ultimately they'll have no choice but to believe you.
answer: It's not enough, don't you understand? I know it happened -- but by every standard of science, by every standard I've lived my life by that fact is utterly beside the point. It may be true but it doesn't matter because I can't prove it's real.

question: Ellie, the only one holding you to that standard is you! The people want to hear your story, they need to hear it!
answer: But --

question: Have you seen what's happening out there? The terror, the despair? The world is on fire, Ellie. People need something they can believe in, something worthy, and you can give it to them!
answer: I want to, Palmer -- more than anything. But it has to be real. It has to be true.

question: Ellie... if you go out there like this -- if you admit to even the possibility that what you experienced didn't actually happen -- I'm afraid they really will crucify you. Please. For your own sake, for the sake of the world... tell them what you know to be the truth. Tell them it really happened.
answer: Earth time, yes. Senator... I believe I traveled through a series of wormholes. Wormholes are a phenomenon deduced by Einstein; they're essentially tears in the fabric of space/time. Because of the effects of relativity what I experienced as a period of approximately eighteen hours passed almost instantaneously on Earth. To you I seemed to depart and arrive back at the same moment.

question: Earth time, yes. Senator... I believe I traveled through a series of wormholes. Wormholes are a phenomenon deduced by Einstein; they're essentially tears in the fabric of space/time. Because of the effects of relativity what I experienced as a period of approximately eighteen hours passed almost instantaneously on Earth. To you I seemed to depart and arrive back at the same moment.
answer: Doctor, isn't it true that wormholes are merely predictions of relativity theory? That there's no evidence they actually exist?

question: There is no direct evidence, no.
answer: And current theory holds that to sustain the sort of wormholes you're talking about, even for a fraction of a second, would require more energy than our sun produces in a year, is that correct?

question: I don't have the figures in front of me, but yes, that sounds about right.
answer: In fact, by all the laws of physics we know what you claim to have experienced is simply impossible.

question: By our standards... yes.
answer: ... And this is how the extraterrestrial presented himself to you? As your father?

question: Yes, sir.
answer: He died... ... in 1972.

question: Yes, sir.
answer: Dr. Arroway, do you think it's possible you had some kind of... delusional episode.

question: Is it possible...?
answer: All the elements are there. A woman, orphaned young, under a great deal of stress. The failure of a project she's staked her self-worth and very sense of identity on -- induces a fantasy of reuniting with her 'father in heaven' as it were. Is it possible?
